images.copyright: Duomo Santa Maria del Fiore at dusk, Florence, Italy (© Elena Pueyo/Getty Images)
images.title: Dome sweet dome
images.caption: Duomo Santa Maria del Fiore, Florence
images.desc: Welcome to Florence, the cradle of the Renaissance! Let the Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore transport you through time. More than just a church, this Gothic structure, with its red-tiled dome, is steeped in centuries of history. Built over an older cathedral dedicated to Santa Reparata, construction began in 1296 under the supervision of architect Arnolfo di Cambio. Filippo Brunelleschi, an Italian architect and designer, engineered its dome, which is the largest brick dome ever constructed. It was built without the support of traditional wooden frameworks; its completion in 1436 was the final stage of the cathedral's construction.

og.title: Duomo Santa Maria del Fiore, Florence

images.copyright: Juvenile Banggai cardinalfish with sea anemone, Lembeh Strait, North Sulawesi, Indonesia (© Constantinos Petrinos/NPL/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Stripe-tacular!
images.caption: Banggai cardinalfish with sea anemone
images.desc: Dive deep beneath the waves surrounding the Banggai Islands in Indonesia and meet the Banggai cardinalfish. Cardinalfish can grow up to 8 centimetres and have tiny shimmery bodies with black vertical stripes and white-edged fins, which help them disguise. Unlike some finned creatures that migrate long distances, these pint-sized fish inhabit a small world, rarely straying far from their local reefs.

images.copyright: The Fire Wave, a rock formation in Valley of Fire State Park, Nevada (© Clint Losee/Tandem Stills + Motion)
images.title: Hot spot for a cool photo
images.caption: Valley of Fire State Park, Nevada
images.desc: Amid the arid expanse of the Mojave Desert in Nevada, USA lies the natural grandeur of the Valley of Fire State Park. This park, which stretches across 19,000 hectares, is named after the fiery red Aztec Sandstone, an Early Jurassic geological formation made up of ancient sand dunes. The park's highlight, Fire Wave, is a geological marvel that appears like a frozen wave with its red, pink and white stripes.
images.bsTitle: Hot spot for a cool photo

images.copyright: Volcanic crater lakes on Kelimutu, Flores, Indonesia (© Shane P. White/Minden Pictures)
images.title: The views will blue your mind
images.caption: Kelimutu, Flores, Indonesia
images.desc: You might have seen lakes with some unique colours before, but the Indonesian island of Flores, with its volcano Kelimutu, may steal the show. Home to three lakes, each with its own hue and folklore, this natural wonder attracts travellers seeking an otherworldly experience. Volcanic vents deep within the Earth release steam and gas, which alter the lakes' mineral compositions, causing reactions that transform their appearance periodically.
images.bsTitle: The views will blue your mind

images.copyright: Aerial view of a roundabout in Dhaka, Bangladesh (© Azim Khan Ronnie/Amazing Aerial Agency)
images.title: Dark night, city lights
images.caption: Dhaka, Bangladesh
images.desc: Cultural opulence, bustling economy and spirited locals—welcome to Dhaka in Bangladesh! This megacity on the Ganges Delta, home to over 10.2 million people, is one of the most densely populated cities on the planet. Once known as Jahangirnagar after ruling emperor Jahangir, Dhaka was the provincial capital of the Mughal Empire for 75 years in total. Dhaka has been nicknamed 'City of Mosques' because of the hundreds of elegant minarets that dot the city.

images.title: Getting lost in the mist
images.caption: World Rainforest Day
images.desc: Fresh air, lush foliage, rustling leaves and calls of thousands of species of animals and birds—welcome to the Amazon rainforest. Today, on World Rainforest Day, let's give a shout-out to this region. Covering over 5,500,000 square kilometres, this ecological treasure in South America extends its branches across nine nations—Brazil, Peru, Colombia, Bolivia, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Suriname and Venezuela.

images.copyright: Interior exhibits of the Canadian Museum of History (© Inspired By Maps/Shutterstock)
images.title: Happy Indigenous Day!
images.caption: National Indigenous Peoples Day
images.desc: National Indigenous Peoples Day is observed on June 21 to honour the rich cultures, languages and traditions of First Nations, Inuit and Métis communities. It was established in 1996 to highlight Indigenous peoples' resilience, creativity and their imprints on the country's multicultural tapestry. On this day, communities come together to celebrate through music, dance, art and traditions.

images.copyright: Kokino, an ancient megalithic observatory, North Macedonia (© stoimilov/Shutterstock)
images.title: Sunrise on the Solstice
images.caption: Summer solstice
images.desc: It's that time of year again—the daylight stretches long into the evening hours! This phenomenon, known as the summer solstice, occurs when one of the Earth's poles is most inclined toward the sun. Today's image features the Kokino megalithic observatory, which is part of the Kokino archaeological site in North Macedonia. It is believed that the Kokino observatory marked the position of the sun during summer and winter solstices, as well as the equinox, and consists of two platforms. A stone block on the upper platform of the observatory indicates the summer solstice sunrise direction when seen from a seat on the lower platform. So, when in North Macedonia, don't miss out on experiencing this ancient astronomical wonder!
